title: TwitterSearch: A Comparison of Microblog Search and Web Search
segmentation: Now I'm at Microsoft Research and this is work I did with Dan Ramage who's at Stanford.
Anne Marie Morris is at MSR with me, so we're looking at microblog search and how people search microblog content and how that compares to how they search web content and.
You know microblog content is really interesting.
It's it's different from the way that web content is.
It's shorter, it doesn't have links, and we suspect that people use it in a different way, and that's how we're going to.
We're going to talk about here.
Twitter is a really common example of microblog content over spoke, focusing specifically on Twitter.

Like Bing and Google are you know, indexing peoples tweets, surfacing ways for you to be able to search them and find information.

In different ways, you know, here's one that does a different kind of display than we're used to, and pulls in other types of social can't.
And on your mobile device, there's also all sorts of ways to be able to access and search microblog content.
I don't even know a fraction of them there.
This is a few.
And here in the academic community, we're also excited about microblog search.

So I went through the wisdom proceedings for the just the past two years and pulled out all the papers that had Twitter or microblog in their keywords or title and came up with all of these and I'm sure I missed some that are relevant and I'm sure there's more when you look at the broader community.
So Twitter search is something that's got a lot of excitement around it.
We're all really interested in how people use this content, but we don't really actually know what they are.
Doing with it.
So how does microblog search look like?
Web search.
How does it look different than in order to build these tools and support the user experience in the way that we want to?
We have to know more about that and you know, you may think, well, we know a lot about web search, so we can just kind of transfer those learnings from web search over to Twitter.
But you know, there's a lot of things that are different.

When you look back at the early web search log analysis, you can see that people were really surprised about the way that the web search worked as compared to the kinds of search that they were that they were used to looking at library search or legal searches or searches that were happening on smaller corpora.
And you know, even though it's only 10 to 15 years ago when you re read these papers, it's fascinating to see the things that sort of surprised people.
It's also kind of fascinating 'cause it's just so much smaller scale they've got, you know thousands of queries instead of millions of queries in their analysis.
It's fun to see, so one of the things that you see when you read early early early log analysis papers is that people were surprised that the queries weren't seven or eight terms long.
And it just seems so intuitive and obvious now that web queries are two to three words long, so it's sort of interesting to think about it being surprising that they're not longer, you know.
And this is when you come from a background of a library search and are thinking more about trained searchers or people who are doing research in the kinds of searches that they run.
People were surprised at advance operators weren't used, so again this sort of relates to the way that people responded.

Change on the web and are no longer these advanced users and instead are novice users, and it's also kind of funny in these early in these early papers people are surprised advanced operators or misused.
So search engines support Boolean logic and might have a capital or capital.
And as a advanced operator.
So they've done log analysis looking for every time and appeared in lower case and called data misuse of the Boolean operator, which I thought was sort of funny.
Um?
They were surprised nobody uses relevance feedback, relevance.
Feedback seemed like it was going to be really popular for library search was taking off, but on the web nobody was using it.
They were also surprised at the topics people were searching for.
You know everybody searches for sex on the web.
It's not something that you see in library search, so.
People are using web content in different ways that also relates to the kind of the different kinds of structure.

So you see, people start issuing navigational queries because all of a sudden there's this opportunity that you can find a resource and then move on and collect information from that particular resource.

With all of these surprises come because the prior experience going into web search was with library search and so I think similarly as we started thinking about different kinds of search that people are doing, like microblog search, it's worth thinking about what our expectations are based on the on the tools that we're using and how it changes when you start moving into a new medium or a new.
Interaction.

So here we've got the microblog search example, and we're going to think about what are the surprises, and so let's get started thinking about sort of what other surprises or what are the things that are different.
Microblog search by looking at what's different about it?

So probably the most obvious and immediate difference is that Twitter search ranks its results by time and on the web we rank results by relevance, so you end up seeing just whatever is the most recent as opposed to whatever is kind of uniformly decided to be relevant.
And then you see a lot of clues about time in the search result page as well, so you see time since the post was treated as sort of a top factor.
And when new content shows up, it'll inform you that there's no tweets.
It would be surprising if you were searching on the web for the query Twitter search in Bing all of a sudden was like, hey, we've got more results that we just crawled.
It's not something that we're used to on web search, but it's something that's really common on on Twitter.

We also see that the content of the result is really different, so 100% of the result content on a microblog search is present in the result page, whereas on when you're doing a web search, that content that is presented on the result page is more of an advertisement trying to tell you whether the underlying resources actually relevant to what you're looking for or not.
And so you can, so that impacts the way that people interact with the content.
We also see that there's a special emergent try kind of syntactic trends in Twitter, so people use hashtags to indicate topics, and these these things.
These hashtags here, for example Twitter search are hyperlinked an issue is search, and you search themselves when you click on it.
There's another convention also with the at symbol in front of a user name that indicates that you're looking for a person and you click on that and that will bring you to that user's page.
And these are emergent trends kind of arose out of the way that people were using Twitter search.
Twitter content in general.
We also see that people are really important, so Twitter presents its results with a lot of information about the people who actually posted the content.

It maybe it's comparable to what like a URL is on a web search result where you're trying to tell you something about sort of the how much you can trust the content or the authority that content, or where it's coming from and get some some sort of perspective.
So all of these things work together to try to influence the way that people are going to use microblog search.
And we're going to look now at how that influences the queries people issue and the patterns of queries that people issue.
So we looked at it from a number of different directions.
One thing we did was we ran a study of 54 Microsoft users.
People who use Twitter and search Twitter to sort of get a qualitative notion of what people are doing when they when they search Twitter, how they find information on Twitter.
We also ran a large scale query log analysis and.

Here we looked at the we used opt in user data from a toolbar that collected information about the websites that people visited and we looked at the queries that people issued to Twitter.com, and we worked with just Twitter.com.

Because there's so many different ways and so many different interfaces for doing microblog search that we thought it was best to restrict ourselves to one to kind of control for all those variations.
We had a sample of 33,000 users who issued queries over 2 weeks and they issued about 126 thousand queries.

Twitter over that period of time and then for that same set of users we went and extracted the queries that they issued to major web search engine so that we could compare within users the way that people are searching the web and microblog content.
And so we've got those.
So it's going to be a little bit different than your typical web behavior because it's these are people who are Twitter users and Twitter searchers, so they may be a little bit more technical.
Technically savvy, they probably use the web a little bit longer.
But we've collected 2.5 million queries from that, so right off the bat you can see there searching the web a lot more than their searching microblog content.
And then we also conducted a comparison of the search results that these queries return to get an idea of sort of what's the difference in the content that gets returned for the same query.
Is it the same stuff that you're getting when you issue the same query to a web search engine or a microblog search engine?
Or is it different things and in this?
Talk, I'm just going to focus on the stuff that we did on the query log analysis.
In the interest of time, but I refer you to the paper for the rest of.
And I'm going to talk specifically about the queries that we saw that people issued to Twitter and how that compared with how they issued queries to the web search engine.
I'm going to talk about temporal patterns in how people search, and then I'm going to talk about the behavior that people had when they moved between web search and Twitter search.
So what kind of queries did they carry over?
How did it look?
How did it look like they were using the two services in can?

So let's start.
These are the top web queries issued and we've heard some talk about navigational queries already, and you'll see that the top ten queries among our users are all navigational.

You see, a slight bias towards the social network sites at the top because we've got we're looking at a subset of users who use social network sites.
And right off the bat, you know that the Twitter queries are going to look very different because Twitter queries can't be navigational.
So you know, you're going to expect some diff.

And so these are the top 10 Twitter queries for the same set of users and you can see some interesting patterns here that are that are actually kind of indicative of what's going on in Twitter in general.

Got some hashtags like hash.
You know you're ugly if you've got some celebrity names.

We also have New Moon came out and video game was released and you also see those queries in the top that was that was events or things that were happening right at the time, and we've got all of these memes.
These sort of social trends.
What are people talking about it this instant?

And then you also see that there's a lot of syntax in these queries that they all have that.

Super.
So we saw a lot of celebrity names in the top ten queries, so we decided to look at how often the celebrity queries were in the data set in general.
So we compiled a list of celebrity names.
Add some publicly available list of names and we added a bunch of hand coded names from the query list as well and we found that 15% of the Twitter queries are celebrity names.
And this is 5 times more than the queries that you see on the web search.
So clearly people are looking for this sort of people related content celebrity content.

But when you look at queries that contain a celebrity name but aren't actually just a celebrity name, you see that people are much more likely to be searching for kind of broader information about the celebrity on the web compared to Twitter.
So when we look at the queries that mention a celebrity, so this is instead of Lady Gaga, it would be Lady Gaga meat dress.

As your query, you see that you're 3 times more likely to have that query issued on the web as compared to on Twitter, so you can see even while people are kind of comparably interested in celebrities in the way that they approach.
Both of these are looking for different information on the two of these are using the search experience search engine in a different way.
In addition to celebrities, celebrities are kind of people that we sort of all know.

People were also looking for individual users on Twitter, so we looked at the at symbol convention where people were mentioning usernames preceded by an at symbol, and we find that 3% of the queries were specifically for a particular using username.
We also wanted to get an idea of how often people were not using the kind of syntactic convention of the at symbol to search for a username.
So we took the list of the usernames and removed the at symbol and then looked at how common those were as well.
And found that there were a lot of queries that looked like that as well.
It looks like people were looking for usernames, but they weren't using the syntax that Twitter supports.
And hashtags were really common as well.
We found 21.3% of the Twitter queries contained a hashtag and very very many fewer on the web.
Contain hashtags and on the web when people use hashtags, they're usually referring to number like #46 in the LA Lakers as opposed to you know, you're ugly if.

And again we also looked at these hashtags without the preceding hash, and you find that there's some more on the web here of the hashtags or people are looking for these sort of trending topics that are interesting to people in general, both on the web and on Twitter.
So I think it's worth thinking a little bit about the about the specialized syntax, 'cause it's such an interesting part of Twitter content and how Twitter is used.
The at symbol an the pound symbol were both common and in some ways are like advanced operators on the web, which we know people don't use in in that they reduce ambiguity.
So if I search for like hash Wisdom 2011, that means I'm looking for maybe all the tweets that people in this room are putting out.

Right now if I search for at Wisdom 2011 I'm looking for perhaps official information coming from the Twitter account, buy it if I search for just Wisdom 2011, I may be looking from different kinds of information, so in some ways it helps reduce the ambiguity of my query.

But there is important, but they're showing up a lot, and I think the reason that they're showing up a lot because of several key important differences between those that syntax one is it's part of the content creation.
So people who use Twitter are using this syntax all the time as part of going out there.
Using hashtags are using at symbols, whereas in web search people who are creating the content aren't using pluses or minuses or capital, and those aren't.
Those aren't things that people are using an.
Also hashtags are queries, so you can actually.
When you put it into the into a into a tweet, you can click on it and it actually goes and issues that query for you.
So we have a lot of people issuing queries on Twitter in a different manner than on the web on the web, primarily queries or manually typed in where is on Twitter.
We're seeing a lot of instances where people go and click links to get information.
And one of the things that that results in most likely is hashtags being very popular.
So you see that there's a.
There's a among the most popular queries.

There are a lot of hashtags, and among the unpopular queries there are relatively fewer hashtags, so there's sort of this real kind of communal aspect of the hashtags where everybody is doing the same thing and that kind of makes sense too.
It's not interesting to search for hashtags that nobody else is interested in, because the hashtags are a way for us to sort of have a group conversation and have other people interested.
In the same topic at the same time.
Celebrity queries were also particularly popular.
Most popular queries contain celebrities 25% of the time.
Where is the least popular queries contained?

Celebrity names only 4% of the time, and you know another thing that's probably going on with these things, like celebrities or hashtags being popular is these are these are kind of current events, things that are happening right now, and so you get a lot of sort of a smaller vocabulary happening around that.
There's only one celebrity who got drunk and passed out last night that we're all going to search for today.
And so that ends up in a smaller vocabulary as that trends and then tomorrow is a different celebrity.
That's interesting and you know it may not be Lady Gaga.
That's the top Twitter query today.
It may be Justin Bieber and we're searching for that one in a different way.

And I think this is part of the reason that we see Twitter queries are less diverse than web queries, so only one in four of the Twitter queries that we had in our data set where unique, whereas half of the of the web queries are unique.
So people are using the same vocabulary.
The queries are short.
We're all talking about the same thing, and it's about getting to be part of that group conversation and hear what other people are thinking.

So we see people repeat the same query alot on Twitter, so 35% of our web queries were repeat queries which is consistent with related literature on re finding on the web that people do a lot of this.
A lot of this repeat search.

So we see that the number of queries in the session on the web that there's a few more queries in a session.
We also see there's a lot more unique queries in a session at the sessions are a little bit longer if people are spending a longer time between their queries versus sort of.
Refreshing and just getting the newest content and seeing what else is there?
And that makes sense too.

The same query to a web search engine as they issued to the Twitter search engine, so we were interested in diving into this a little bit deeper.

on Twitter, we see that similarly happening when we're looking at the sessions that always this common query is just issued, just as a common query over and over again on Twitter.

Twitter to monitor information you know.
